user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of try_get_value:
```c
static void
try_get_value (const char *buf,
               const char *key,
               char **destination)
{
  const char *spos;
  const char *bpos;
  const char *endv;
  size_t klen;
  size_t vlen;

  if (NULL != *destination)
    return;
  bpos = buf;
  klen = strlen (key);
  while (NULL != (spos = strstr (bpos, key)))
  {
    if ( (spos[klen] != '=') ||
         ( (spos != buf) &&
           (spos[-1] != ' ') ) )
    {
      /* no match */
      bpos = spos + 1;
      continue;
    }
    if (spos[klen + 1] != '"')
      return;                   /* not quoted */
    if (NULL == (endv = strchr (&spos[klen + 2],
                                '\"')))
      return;                   /* no end-quote */
    vlen = (size_t) (endv - spos) - klen - 1;
    *destination = malloc (vlen);
    if (NULL == *destination)
      return;                   /* out of memory */
    (*destination)[vlen - 1] = '\0';
    memcpy (*destination,
            &spos[klen + 2],
            vlen - 1);
    return;                     /* success */
  }
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I found no uses of compiler-specific or nonstandard language extensions in the provided function. The code only uses standard C constructs and library functions (strlen, strstr, strchr, malloc, memcpy) and standard operators (pointer arithmetic, indexing, casts). There are no occurrences of known compiler extensions such as __attribute__, __builtin_*, typeof, asm, statement-expressions ({ ... }), nested functions, labels-as-values, zero-length/ flexible array misuse, nonstandard calling conventions, or compiler pragmas. The cast to size_t and pointer arithmetic are standard C, and all declarations follow standard syntax. Therefore there are no fragments that need investigation for Rule 1.2 (use of language extensions).
